Award.AwardTitle: The DREAM STEM Project: "STEMulating" Innovation and Entrepreneurship

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program provides support projects to design, implement, and assess strategies that can lead to comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The project at North Carolina Central University seeks to produce the next generation of scientists who are creative problem solvers, self-directed learners, innovators, knowledge generators, and economic stimulators. The overall goal is to significantly increase the retention and graduation rate of underrepresented minority students at the University choosing career paths in STEM majors, graduate programs, and workforce.

The activities and strategies involve: implementing a proactive advising system; contributing to students' science identity development; launching problem-based learning pedagogy in undergraduate mathematics and science courses; and stimulating innovation and entrepreneurial thinking. The activities and strategies are evidence-based and what is learned through this project can serve as a model for other institutions. The project is informed by an on-going evaluation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major aim of this one-year project was to pilot new initiatives that could enhance STEM teaching and learning and to expand infusing innovation and entrepreneurship experiences and training in the academic and professional development of students seeking to earn STEM degrees.

Intellectual Merit:

Drawing on lessons learned from previous work, this project takes a “holistic” approach to assure retention through multiple strategies including financial assistance, proactive advising, academic support services, mentoring, and enrichment. The activities piloted involved: (1) implementing a proactive advising system; (2) contributing to students’ science identity development; (3) launching project-based learning (PBL) pedagogy in undergraduate mathematics and science courses; and (4) stimulating innovation and entrepreneurial thinking development.

A dedicated Academic Advisor and Adjunct Assistant professor led implementation of proactive advising of physics/engineering dual degree program students utilizing SuccessNavigator®, Grades First®, BANNER, one-on-one advising sessions, counseling services, and various other student support mechanisms. Most effective was the activity of identifying 3+2 students early in the 1st semester and having a one-on-one introductory meeting has produced the largest effect and best outcome. Students were most responsive to one-on-one advising sessions with the Advisor and would often utilize the open-door policy to discuss their course progress and other academic issues. Even a single meeting solidified the student’s connection with the 3+2 advisor and helped acclimate the student to the department.  For the PBL in STEM Courses, surveys of students who participated in PBL-infused Calculus I and General Chemistry I classes: (1) Nearly 60% agreed that the project improved their communication skills and helped them to communicate effectively with others; (2) over 60% agreed that their time management improved; (3) nearly 80% agreed that their problem-solving ability improved; and (4) less than 50% felt strongly that their confidence increased. Overall, there were very positive early indications that the PBL-infused classes were engaging and motivating to students. The pass rate in PBL-infused General Physics I was 62% compared to 47.3% for the prior 6-year average. The pass rate in PBL-infused General Chemistry I was 67% compared to 38% for the prior 6-year average.

Broader Impacts:

During this one-year project, four undergraduate students were supported to conduct research with faculty in on-campus research labs, and three students were supported in off-campus industry internships with tech start-up companies. In addition, a Research, Discovery, & Innovation Summer Institute with design & entrepreneurial thinking experiences was provided to seven new and continuing STEM students following their participation in a regional drone camp. A two-semester Freshman STEM Project Design Course was designed and approved and offered in fall semester 2018. In promoting intellectual property (IP) careers in STEM, 60% of freshman biology students surveyed indicated a moderate to very high interest in IP, which is a proxy for showing a strong demand for the creation of the proposed IP Career Prep Program for STEM majors.
